audioDescription: A heavily vegetated mangrove island with white beaches and a blue outhouse amongst brackish waters.

title: Joe River Chickee
listingDescription: This double chickee campsite is located on an alternate route from the Wilderness Waterway on the east bank of the mouth of Joe River. The chickee sits in a small but beautiful cove. At night, listen for dolphins who puff their way past your home to fish in the creek behind the chickee. Tall trees block all but southwesterly breezes, so be prepared for tiny winged visitors.
bodyText:
This double chickee campsite is located on an alternate route from the Wilderness Waterway on the east bank of the mouth of Joe River. The chickee sits in a small but beautiful cove. At night, listen for dolphins who puff their way past your home to fish in the creek behind the chickee. Tall trees block all but southwesterly breezes, so be prepared for tiny winged visitors.

Access - Accessible at all tides by powerboat, canoe, and kayak. From the Wilderness Waterway, travel southwest from marker #2 through Oyster Bay. Traveling through Joe River between Oyster Bay and Flamingo affords some protection from gusty winds and rough water common on Whitewater Bay, although Joe Bay can get quite rough on windy days.
audioDescription: A double chickee campsite with two roofed square platforms, open on all sides, and connected by a small walkway centered with a vault toilet. This site is located on an alternate route from the Wilderness Waterway on the northeast bank at the mouth of the blue-green waters of Joe River. The chickee sits in a small cove with mangrove backdrops. Accessible at all tides by boat, from the Wilderness Waterway by traveling southwest from marker #2 through Oyster Bay.

title: Lard Can Campsite
listingDescription: This ground campsite is located on a small patch of slightly elevated ground. It is shaded by buttonwoods and surrounded by mangroves. Soil compaction at the site makes it very muddy after a rainstorm. The thick vegetation and shade can lead to high mosquito levels, especially in summer.
bodyText:
This ground campsite is located on a small patch of slightly elevated ground. It is shaded by buttonwoods and surrounded by mangroves. Soil compaction at the site makes it very muddy after a rainstorm. The thick vegetation and shade can lead to high mosquito levels, especially in summer.

Access - Accessible by paddlers from the Hell’s Bay Trail. Motors are prohibited from the Hells Bay Trail Head to Lard Can. The trail winds through mangroves and is protected from the wind for most of the way. White numbered PVC poles mark the route.
audioDescription: The soil covered campsite has a vault toilet. Located on a small patch of slightly elevated ground. It is shaded by buttonwoods and surrounded by mangroves. Soil covers the site which is accessed by a small planked dock and boardwalk above the tannin rich water at the northern end of the Hell’s Bay Trail. White numbered PVC poles mark the route.

title: Long Pine Key Trail
listingDescription: Connecting trails through the Pinelands run 7 miles (11 km) west from the Long Pine Key campground to Pine Glades Lake along the main park road. It is advisable to look at trail map to understand the network of trails.

images.altText: Helmeted bikers follow a ranger down a dirt path. Tall slash pine trees line both sides
images.title: Long Pine Key Trail
images.caption: Visitors Bike through the pine rockland habitat on Long Pine Key Trail

bodyText: Cutting across shrubby pineland forest, this wide, rocky trail winds from Long Pine Key Rd west over 7miles (11km) to Pine Glades Lake through the heart of the Everglades rarest ecosystem. Birds, bugs, and blossoms abound along palmetto lined corridors of South Florida slash pines. Aside from seasonal washout zones through waterlogged prairie, the trail is dominated by dry, exposed limestone dotted with shallow pools. At the trails end by main park road, waterfowl, fish, and reptiles frequent the shores of Pine Glades Lake.
audioDescription: The Long Pine Key Trail begins on the side of the road past a brown park gate. There is a brown rectangular sign on the side of the road that reads “Long Pine Key Nature Trail” with a white arrow pointing to the trail. Loose rocks, exposed limestone and patchy grass make up the substrate for the trail. Large pine trees tower overhead and small shrubs and trees are immediately on either side of the trail. A rectangular wayside sign stands on the side of the trail. The trail is primarily exposed limestone rock and patches of grasses.

title: Lopez River Campsite
listingDescription: Closest campsite on the Wilderness Waterway to Everglades City, located between marker #126 and #127 on the southern bank of the Lopez River. This campsite is easily located by spotting the cement cistern which marks the old Lopez homestead built at the turn of the century.

images.altText: A small clearing in dense mangroves. A small bare spot is next to a blue vault toilet
images.title: Lopez River Campsite
images.caption: The Lopez River is the closest campsite to Everglades City

bodyText:
Closest campsite on the Wilderness Waterway to Everglades City, located between marker #126 and #127 on the southern bank of the Lopez River. This campsite is easily located by spotting the cement cistern which marks the old Lopez homestead built at the turn of the century.

audioDescription: On a heavily vegetated mangrove island a patch of earth slopes out of the brown brackish waters before it flattens out and continues further into the woods. A blue outhouse sits on the edge of the woods next to the slope.

title: Lostman's Five Campsite
listingDescription: A ground campsite located on a clearing of higher ground with a few palm trees that provide shade. This site was once an inholding. Soil compaction at this site can cause flooding during rainy weather. The dock is larger than most and can accommodate several vessels. This is a popular site for fishing groups with powerboats.

images.altText: A small dock with a blue vault toilet. A clearing in the vegetation leads to camp clearing
images.title: Lostman's Five Campsite
images.caption: Lostman's Five is a remote camp in the wilderness

audioDescription: A boardwalk raised above dark brackish water leads into the woods on a heavily vegetated mangrove island. A blue outhouse and sign designating “Lostman’s Five” adorn the boardwalk.

title: Mahogany Hammock
listingDescription: This self-guiding boardwalk trail meanders through a dense, jungle-like hardwood "hammock." Lush vegetation includes gumbo-limbo trees, air plants, and the largest living mahogany tree (Swietenia mahogani) in the United States. The trail is 0.5 miles (800 meters) roundtrip and is wheelchair accessible.

images.altText: A light colored wooden boardwalk stretches into a densely vegetated green canopy
images.title: Mahogany Hammock
images.caption: The Mahogany Hammock trail winds through a forest of dense hardwood trees

bodyText: This self-guiding boardwalk trail meanders through a dense, jungle-like hardwood "hammock." Lush vegetation includes gumbo-limbo trees, air plants, and the largest living mahogany tree (Swietenia mahogani) in the United States. The trail is 0.5 miles (800 meters) roundtrip and is wheelchair accessible.
audioDescription: The Mahogany Hammock trail begins at the end of a paved parking lot. The parking area is paved and surrounded by tall trees and palms. A rectangular wayside sign that briefs visitors is located at the trailhead. The wayside sign has a black band at the top that reads Everglades National Park. The sign has a barred owl pictured in a tree. The sign is Titled “Mahogany Hammock Trail” and has text that reads “This boardwalk bridges the sawgrass river and enters a lush tree island – a tropical hammock. Hidden from historic logging activities, old-growth mahogany trees have grown to record size on the hammock’s higher, drier ground. The boardwalk’s back section rises through the hammock from dense undergrowth up toward the tree canopy, where owls and air plants thrive. The trail terrain is a boardwalk that runs through a sawgrass prairie which gives views of distant tree islands. The trail leads to a dense tree island known as a hammock with tall trees that create a canopy overhead as you travel the boardwalk trail.

title: Middle Cape Campsite
listingDescription: This beach campsite, popular with fishermen, is a long, shelly sand beach on the Gulf of Mexico. There is little shade, and it is exposed to wind in all directions. Campers will find spectacular sunrises and sunsets and unparalleled views of the Gulf or Mexico. Raccoons are in the area; store food and water appropriately.

images.altText: A brown and gray bird with a yellow streak over its eye perches on a tuft of grassy vegetation
images.title: Cape Sable Seaside Sparrow
images.caption: An endangered Cape Sable Seaside Sparrow perches on grasses

bodyText:
This beach campsite, popular with fishermen, is a long, shelly sand beach on the Gulf of Mexico. There is little shade, and it is exposed to wind in all directions. Campers will find spectacular sunrises and sunsets and unparalleled views of the Gulf or Mexico. Raccoons are in the area; store food and water appropriately.

Access - Accessible by powerboat, canoe or kayak via Florida Bay and the Gulf of Mexico. The site is exposed; canoes and kayaks should be pulled far onto shore in case the wind picks up. Powerboats should anchor from the bow in unfavorable weather to avoid swamping.

Safely exploring a wilderness by water requires careful preparation and planning. Please visit our Wilderness Trip Planner page to learn more.
audioDescription: The campsites are on a long, shelly sand beach adjacent to the light blue-tan waters of the Gulf of Mexico backdropped by mostly low-lying grassy vegetation and bushes. This site does not have a toilet. Accessible by boat via Florida Bay and the Gulf of Mexico and located on the southwestern shore of Cape Sable.

title: Mormon Key
listingDescription: Beach campsite. There is good fishing in the area located near the mouth of the Huston and Chatham Rivers. Make sure your camp is set up above the high tide line. Make sure vessels are tied, beached, or anchored securely.

images.altText: A white curved sandy beach with shells and seaweed. blue waters and green vegetation
images.title: Mormon Key
images.caption: Mormon Key is a good place for beach solitude

audioDescription: Lightly colored sand beach on the edge of a heavily vegetated mangrove island.

title: Mrazek Pond
listingDescription: Most of the year only a few ducks and wading birds, but for a few days during some winters, large numbers of wading birds, including Roseate Spoonbills and Wood Storks, move in to feast. Mrazek Pond is located approximately 3 miles north of the Flamingo Visitor Center.

images.altText: Two photographers point their cameras at hundreds of white wading birds feeding in the water
images.title: Birding- Mrazek Pond
images.caption: Mrazek Pond with busy bird activity

bodyText: Most of the year you'll see only a few ducks and wading birds, but for a few days during some winters, large numbers of wading birds, including Roseate Spoonbills and Wood Storks, move in to feast. Mrazek Pond is located approximately 3 miles north of the Guy Bradley Visitor Center.
audioDescription: Facing to the southeast from the east end of the paved vehicle pullout along the east bound lane of the main park road lies Mrazek Pond. This is approximately 33.6 miles from the main park entrance. The area is bordered by a variety of living and dead mangroves, this body of dark tannin, occasionally muddy water is popular with wading birds and seasonal flocks of pelicans. The waters edge is 40 feet from the pavement with a 70-foot wide grassy shoreline clearing with an overhead clear of vegetation.

title: Mud Lake Canoe Trail
listingDescription: This trail is 7 miles round trip from Coot Bay Pond. Venture inland through the mangroves on this trail connecting the Buttonwood Canal, Coot Bay, Mud Lake, and Bear Lake. Birding is often good at Mud Lake. Accessible from the Bear Lake Trailhead (note Bear Lake Canoe Trail is Impassable) or Coot Bay Pond. Motors no allowed.

images.altText: Pink flamingos wade in murky water at Mud Lake. Some have their heads and necks underwater
images.title: Flamingos at Mud Lake
images.caption: Pink flamingos wading in Mud Lake

bodyText: This trail is 7 miles round trip from Coot Bay Pond. Venture inland through the mangroves on this trail connecting the Buttonwood Canal, Coot Bay, Mud Lake, and Bear Lake. Birding is often good at Mud Lake. Accessible from the Bear Lake Trailhead (note: Bear Lake Canoe Trail is impassable) or Coot Bay Pond. Motors not allowed.
audioDescription: The entrance to Mud Lake facing south from Coot Bay opens into a wide, shallow light brown muddy bay spotted with red mangroves. The perimeter of the bay is surrounded with red mangroves. South in the distance you can see white PV markers that will lead you through the bay

title: New Turkey Key Campsite
listingDescription: The beach site in the middle of the key has a vault toilet nearby, but is buggy. The other site is on an open sand spit which usually has less bugs, but at high tide you must use a boat to reach the toilet in the middle of the key. The sand spit is getting smaller and holds less people.

images.altText: White sand with patches of grass growing through. A yellow kayak is beached on the shore in distance
images.title: New Turkey Key
images.caption: New Turkey Key beaches provide opportunities for solitude

bodyText:

audioDescription: White sandy beach with sparse vegetation. There is a blue outhouse on the island.

title: Nine Mile Pond Canoe Trail
listingDescription: Nine Mile Pond is a 5.2 mile loop. This scenic trail passes through shallow grassy marsh with scattered mangrove islands. Watch for alligators, crocodiles, wading birds, and an occasional endangered snail kite. The trail is marked with numbered white poles. Water levels are good for passage in the fall and winter.

images.altText: Visitors sit eating at a picnic table. An alligator swims in the blue water in the background
images.title: Nine Mile Pond
images.caption: Visitors take a break on a picnic table at Nine Mile Pond

bodyText:
Nine Mile Pond is a 5.2 mile loop. This scenic trail passes through shallow grassy marsh with scattered mangrove islands. Watch for alligators, crocodiles, wading birds, and an occasional endangered snail kite. The trail is marked with numbered white poles. Water levels are good for passage in the fall and winter.

Everglades Institute

The Everglades Institute offers guided paddling tours of Nine Mile Pond when water levels permit. Canoes and paddling equipment will be supplied to all guests.

  • Learn more at: Everglades Institute
audioDescription: Nine Mile Pond Canoe Trail is located 32 miles from the park entrance and 11 miles from Flamingo Visitor Center. Two paved access roads, on the left side if coming from the park entrance, lead to a 200 foot long paved parking area next to Nine Mile Pond. A wide grassy area between the parking and the pond provides access for launching boats. A sign at the south end of the parking area provides trail information. There are two picnic tables, however trash must be carried out as there are no trash cans.

title: Noble Hammock Canoe Trail
listingDescription: Noble Hammock is a 2 mile loop winding through a maze of shady mangrove lined creeks and small ponds, the sharp turns and narrow passageways require good maneuvering skills. Enjoy a “crash” course. Check for low water levels during the dry season. Motors prohibited.

images.altText: From the bow of a green kayak, the prop roots of a red mangrove tree reach into the calm water
images.title: Noble Hammock Canoe Trail
images.caption: A kayaker's look at the mangroves along the Noble Hammock Paddling Trail

bodyText: Noble Hammock is a 2 mile loop winding through a maze of shady mangrovelined creeks and small ponds, the sharp turns and narrow passageways require good maneuvering skills. Enjoy a “crash” course. Check for low water levels during the dry season. Motors prohibited.
audioDescription: A road sign marks the start of the Noble Hammock Canoe Trail 28 miles from the park entrance and 10 miles from Flamingo Visitor Center. A 100 foot grass pullout opposite the sign, on the southeast side of the road, provides a parking area. A sign next to the boat launch provides information about the trail. A gap in the mangroves leads to a small platform where boats can be launched into the tannin stained water.

title: North Nest Key
listingDescription: An island beach campsite accessible to powerboats with a multi-vessel dock and vault toilet. The campsite beach is on the west side featuring a relatively thin beach area with short but dense vegetation beyond. Surrounding waters are clean to very light blue. Located less than 10 miles from Upper Florida Keys and 23 miles from the Flamingo Marina

images.altText: Aerial view of green vegetation of North Nest Key surrounded by turquoise blue waters
images.title: North Nest Key
images.caption: Aerial view of beautiful North Nest Key

bodyText:
Ground Site. One of only two keys open to camping in Florida Bay. This site is popular with boaters and can be a very busy area, especially on weekends. Snorkelers should be cautious: use a dive flag with a buddy. And be alert for other boats in the area.

Access - Accessible to powerboats at all tides. Not recommended for paddlers due to long distance over open water, unless launching from Key Largo. The dock will accommodate several vessels. Located five miles west of Upper Florida Keys.

Safely exploring a wilderness by water requires careful preparation and planning. Please visit our Wilderness Trip Planner page to learn more.

title: Northwest Cape Campsite
listingDescription: This beach campsite is an open shelly sand beach with no shade. It is exposed to sun and wind in all directions. Mosquitoes and sandflies may be a present year round. Raccoons are in the area; store food and water in appropriately (hard sided containers). Beautiful sunsets and a sense of wilderness solitude will reward campers here, at this least frequented of the three Cape Sable beaches.

images.altText: A large piece of driftwood lays on brown sandy beach with calm blue waters in the distance
images.title: Cape Sable
images.caption: Driftwood washed along the shore of Cape Sable

audioDescription: This open campsite is on a thin, shelly sand beach with light blue sediment laden water on approach. This site does not have a toilet. Beyond is varying vegetation ranging from waist-high grasses to sizable trees. It is accessible by boat via Florida Bay and the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Old Ingraham Highway
listingDescription: The historic Old Ingraham Highway was the first motorway to Flamingo but now provides at least 10 miles (one way) of backpacking into the heart of the Everglades. There are two backcountry campsites along this trail.

images.altText: A hiker on a trail flanked by shrubby green trees on the left and open sawgrass on the right
images.title: Walking along the Old Ingraham Highway
images.caption: Walking along Old Ingram Highway

bodyText: The historic Old Ingraham Highway was the first motorway to Flamingo but now provides at least 10 miles (one way) of backpacking into the heart of the Everglades. This packed gravel historic road can be flooded during the wetter months but allows wonderful uninterrupted vistas of the Taylor Slough and tree islands looming in the distance.
audioDescription: At half mile from the turn off at Royal Palm road, the Old Ingraham Hiking trail begins with a drivable section of road running perpendicular to research Road. It is a packed concrete road pocked with pot holes and flanked on either side by thick canopied hardwood hammock and flat shallow grasslands indicating a recent restoration area. The hardwood hammock branches extend over portions of the road to provide shade canopy as well as habitat for songbirds and air plants. The strait road extends south for a mile, before ending at a dead end and parking area. A gray metal gate indicates the beginning of the portion of the trail that is only accessible by foot. Two small brown interpretive signs are to the right of the entrance gate. A small foot path around the gate yields to an approximately 6 or 8 foot wide paved trail/path. Designated as a historic trail, the concrete path is old and there is often vegetation poking through cracks in the gray limestone used for construction over 100 years ago. The trail continues south southwest for almost 4 miles before taking a sharp right west for another 6 miles. The beginning portion of the trail is adjacent to a 15 foot high, ¼ mile long vegetation mound that is part of the restoration area. Thick with succeeding vegetation, it is lush and green, speckled with flowers and pollinators. Thick shrubby vegetation line either side of the path as it gradually moves out into an open prairie habitat which is dotted with green hammocks in the distance. At various times of the year, the road may be inundated with water flowing from north to south. Occasionally the path tunnels through deeper and wetter thick cypress forests or small hammocks.

title: Otter Cave Hammock Trail
listingDescription: A short, .3 mile trail over a rough limestone surface. This hammock provides an up close view of the solution holes that permeate the floor of the Everglades, open year round.

images.altText: A winding, uneven path through a dense shaded hammock with thick hardwood trees
images.title: Otter Cave Hammock Trail
images.caption: The Otter Cave Hammock Trail has rough uneven terrain and tall hardwood trees

bodyText: A short, .3 mile trail over a rough limestone surface. This hammock provides an up close view of the solution holes that permeate the floor of the Everglades, open year round.
audioDescription: To find the beginning of the Otter Cave Hammock Trail, walk or bike a half mile south along the west tram road. The trailhead is marked with a sign on the left. This 0.3 mile trail will loop back to the tram road. Past the sign, the trail turns into a mixture of limestone bedrock scattered with solution holes. The trail can be inundated with water during certain times of the year. Proceed with caution as the trail is unpaved and wildlife may dart across or lie silently nearby. The meandering trail immerses you in this special ecosystem of thick, jungle-like tree

title: Pa-hay-Okee
listingDescription: This elevated wooden boardwalk leads to an overlook that offers sweeping vistas of the "river of grass". This raised observation platform provides close up views of dwarf cypress trees, magnolia, air plants and string lillies. The trail is 0.16 miles or 260 meters roundtrip, Wheelchair accessible.

images.altText: An aerial view of the wooden Pa-hay-Okee boardwalk and shelter structure.
images.title: Pa-hay-Okee
images.caption: The Pa-hay-Okee Boardwalk leads to an elevated shade structure that looks over the river of grass

bodyText: This elevated wooden boardwalk leads to an overlook that offers sweeping vistas of the "river of grass". This raised observation platform provides close up views of dwarf cypress trees, magnolia, air plants and string lillies. The trail is 0.16 miles or 260 meters roundtrip, Wheelchair accessible.
audioDescription: As you approach Pay-hay-okee Overlook, you will come across two rows of parking. There is handicap parking as well. Since Pay-hay-okee Overlook is a looped trail, you will start where the trailhead interpretive sign is located. The sign is both in English and in Spanish and it informs you of the distance and provides a short history of this place. The beginning of the trail is an accessible boardwalk ramp that gradually rises to an observation platform. The distance of this trail is 0.2 miles, or 250 meters, so please allow for about 20 to 25 minutes to complete it by walking. As you start walking the trail, you will notice being surrounded by native plants such as Coco Plum, Magnolia, and other trees. The trail is slowly inclining up and then opens up into a clear vista. On the left-hand side of the trail looking north there is an interpretive sign on the boardwalk railing about the bald cypress trees. Since this is an elevated boardwalk, you will be able to clearly observe the height of these cypress trees, as well as the overall area. There is a sheltered overlook that has three interpretive signs in English and Spanish, and there are two sitting benches. The view shows the famed ‘River of Grass’ and you can see many tree islands dotting the landscape. If you continue along the trail, there will be stairs to reach the other half of the boardwalk trail. As you are stepping down the stairs, you will be able to notice sawgrass and other flora closer to you since you have descended from the raised platform. The flat boardwalk allows you to see other things up close, and will eventually lead you back into the parking lot.

title: Paurotis Pond
listingDescription: Paurotis Pond is a scenic point along the Main Park Road. It is a rookery for many wading birds during the nesting season. It offers picnic tables and parking.

images.altText: Blue sky and green vegetation is reflected in the calm waters of Paurotis Pond
images.title: Paurotis Pond
images.caption: Blue water of Paurotis Pond with trees in the distance

bodyText: Paurotis Pond is a scenic point along the Main Park Road. It is a rookery for many wading birds during the nesting season. It offers picnic tables and parking.
audioDescription: The dark green water of this pond is centered with a small vegetation covered circular island. It is located approximately 30 miles from the main park entrance. The pond is about 250 yards to the west off the main park road along a short paved access road with parking spaces and looped turn-around. A variety of vegetation rises to different heights along the pond with several grassy areas allowing access to shoreline segments. A sign near the right side of the looped turn-around indicated paddling and fishing are allowed at this site. Overall dimensions of the pond are 440 yards long by 340 yards wide.

title: Pavilion Key Campsite
listingDescription: Beach camping. Campsites are plentiful, choose a site away from vegetation to minimize the impact on this fragile area. Bird watching is popular on the shoreline and fishing in the area is good. Tie or anchor your vessel securely and protect your food from racoons. DO NOT CAMP ON THE SPIT! Camp only on the shoreline.

images.altText: An orange kayak sits on a beach with a partially cloudy sky in the background
images.title: Pavilion Key
images.caption: A kayak rests at Pavilion Key

bodyText:
The interior of Pavilion Key is closed to protect vulnerable resources. Pavilion Key has a small campsite on the north end that may be used.

Bird watching is popular on the shoreline and fishing in the area is great. Tie or anchor your vessel securely and protect your food from racoons.

Safely exploring a wilderness by water requires careful preparation and planning. Please visit our Wilderness Trip Planner page to learn more.
audioDescription: A white sand beach curling along the water with grassy vegetation turning to heavily vegetated mangroves in the interior of the island.

title: Pearl Bay Chickee
listingDescription: This chickee is designed to accommodate campers with disabilities. The platforms have railings on several sides, and there is a large chemical toilet. One of the platforms has steps leading down to the water to facilitate access. The chickee sits in the bay, away from the surrounding mangroves, and is open at all sides, so mosquitoes usually are not a problem. On a moonless night, the stars are reflected hugely in the still waters of the bay. Dolphins swim past, hunting a mid
bodyText:
This chickee is designed to accommodate campers with disabilities. The platforms have railings on several sides, and there is a large chemical toilet. One of the platforms has steps leading down to the water to facilitate access. The chickee sits in the bay, away from the surrounding mangroves, and is open at all sides, so mosquitoes usually are not a problem. On a moonless night, the stars are reflected hugely in the still waters of the bay. Dolphins swim past, hunting a midnight snack.

Access - Accessible by boat, canoe, and kayak from Whitewater Bay. Accessible by canoe or kayak only, via Hell’s Bay Canoe Trail (starts off park road). The trail is well marked with white PVC poles from the trailhead.
audioDescription: This double chickee campsite has two roofed square platforms, open on all sides, and connected by a small walkway centered with an accessible vault toilet. This is the only chickee designed to accommodate campers with disabilities and includes handrails and other supports. One of the platforms has steps leading down to the water to facilitate access. Accessible by boat from Whitewater Bay, the chickee is located near the upper third of Pearl Bay to the southeast of a mangrove peninsula surrounded by dark tannin-rich water.

title: Picnic Key Campsite
listingDescription: Campsites are located along the narrow beach. The channel offshore of the site is deep and swift with numerous oyster bars on the bottom. This site can be very buggy when calm and is exposed to westerly winds in stormy weather. Camp well above the high tide line.

images.altText: A gray tent is set up on a white sandy beach with green wide leafed sea grape trees behind it
images.title: Picnic Key
images.caption: Camping on Picnic Key

bodyText:
Campsites are located along the narrow beach. The channel offshore of the site is deep and swift with numerous oyster bars on the bottom. This site can be very buggy when calm and is exposed to westerly winds in stormy weather. Camp well above the high tide line.

audioDescription: A long, white sandy beach with thick green vegetation in the interior of the key. The water surrounding the area is clear.

title: Pinelands Trail
listingDescription: Pinelands Trail is a short, paved loop trail is 2 miles west of the Long Pine Key turnoff on the main park road. This trail loops through a forest of pines, palmettos, and wildflowers. It is 0.4 miles (650 meters) roundtrip. Wheelchair accessible.

images.altText: A light gray paved path meanders through green palms. Tall green pine tops reach into a blue sky
images.title: Pinelands Trail
images.caption: A concrete path winds through the shrubby pine rockland habitat

bodyText: Pinelands Trail is a short, paved loop trail is 2 miles west of the Long Pine Key turnoff on the main park road. This trail loops through a forest of pines, palmettos, and wildflowers. It is 0.4 miles (650 meters) roundtrip. Wheelchair accessible.
audioDescription: This trail begins at a gravel parking area on the side of the road. Surrounding the parking lot is a pineland habitat that is made up of mostly Florida slash pine and saw palmetto with hammock habitat species encroaching. A rectangular trail sign sits at the trailhead with the title “Pinelands Trail”. The sign has a background image of a foggy morning at a pine rockland with mature and immature pine tree as a prominent piece to the picture. Below the title is text that reads “This trail loops through one of the most varied habitats in the park. The surrounding sawgrass is a single habitat; this pine island is many. Here the plants are clues to contrasting worlds, from cactus on high ground to the jungle tangle at the edge of a hammock. Pinelands habitats have no fixed borders. Fires and hurricanes shift them and enable these temperate islands to survive in the damp, subtropical environment. Look for charred pine bark and wind snapped trunks.” A picture of a Pileated Woodpecker bird and a picture of a Devil’s Potato plant sit side-by-side below the text. On the opposite side is a map of the trail indicating it is a 0.4 mile trail. The trail should take the average visitor about 30-minutes to complete. The trail is an asphalt trail and is accessible with a wheelchair.

title: Plate Creek Chickee
listingDescription: Chickee campsite located on a small key facing SE. This key gets good air circulation, making it more insect free than most. Free standing tents are needed for chickee

images.altText: A yellow kayak sits atop a wooden platform above the water. A green tent is behind it
images.title: Plate Creek Chickee
images.caption: A kayak on Plate Creek Chickee

bodyText:
Chickee campsite located on a small key facing southeast. This key gets good air circulation, making it more insect-free than most. Free standing tents are needed for the chickee.

audioDescription: A roofed 10’ x 12’ wooden platform elevated above dark water. A blue plastic outhouse sits on a wooden platform without a roof over it. The chickee sits against heavy, green vegetation.

title: Rabbit Key Campsite
listingDescription: This beach campsite site is located at the mouth of Rabbit Key Pass on the eastern side of the island. A vault toilet marks the designated site. This campsite is a narrow beach with dune vegetation. Be aware of prickly pear cactus near toilet.

images.altText: White sandy shoreline with blue water and green vegetation covering the land.
images.title: Rabbit Key
images.caption: Rabbit Key beach campsite

audioDescription: A heavily vegetated mangrove island with white beaches and a blue outhouse amongst brackish waters.

title: Rodger's River Chickee
listingDescription: This double chickee is set in the middle of a small protected cove. It is far enough from the mangroves and situated so that it usually gets a breeze off the water and has few mosquitoes. The nearby bays offer good tarpon fishing and there is access to freshwater bass fishing as well. Eating bass caught in this area is not advised due to high mercury content.

images.altText: Two open air platforms over the water with two roofs. A blue vault toilet is in between them
images.title: Rodger's River Chickee
images.caption: Rodger's River Chickee is a popular spot for tarpon fishing

bodyText:
This double chickee is set in the middle of a small protected cove. It is far enough from the mangroves and situated so that it usually gets a breeze off the water and has few mosquitoes. The nearby bays offer good tarpon fishing and there is access to freshwater bass fishing as well. Eating bass caught in this area is not advised due to high mercury content.

Safely exploring a wilderness by water requires careful preparation and planning. Please visit our Wilderness Trip Planner page to learn more.
audioDescription: There are two 10’ x 12’ elevated wooden platforms that are covered with metal zinc roofs to protect from rain. A wooden horizontal ramp without a roof, and about 24 feet long, connects both platforms. In the middle of this ramp is a blue plastic outhouse. Attached to each chickee there are metal ladders that will help you climb to the chickee during low tides. Brackish water surrounds the site. Behind the chickees there is heavy mangrove vegetation.

title: Rowdy Bend Hiking Trail
listingDescription: Rowdy Bend Trail is 2.6 miles one way. Explore an overgrown old roadbed through shady buttonwoods and open coastal prairie. This is an opportunity for good woodland bird watching. Combine this trail with the Main Park Road (use caution!) and the Snake Bight Trail for a 12.6-mile round–trip bike ride from the Guy Bradley Visitor Center.

images.altText: A wide dirt trail between buttonwoods trees with a bike standing on its kickstand.
images.title: Rowdy Bend Hiking Trail
images.caption: The Rowdy Bend Hiking trail travels through coastal habitats

bodyText: Rowdy Bend Trail is 2.6 miles one way. Explore an overgrown old roadbed through shady buttonwoods and open coastal prairie. This is an opportunity for good woodland bird watching. Combine this trail with the Main Park Road (use caution!) and the Snake Bight Trail for a 12.6-mile round–trip bike ride from the Guy Bradley Visitor Center.
audioDescription: This bare ground trail begins around 10 feet to the south off the main park road and initially has vehicle tire ruts. This is located 32 miles from the main park entrance. Two side-by-side signs are located on the right side of the trail. One indicates “Authorized Motor Vehicles Only” while the other indicates the trail name, distance, availability for hikers and bicyclists, a trail map which also shows where this trail meets the Snake Bight Trail and then additional information. The signed side of the trail is walled by trees while the left side has vegetation of varying heights to include grass, bushes and trees. The overhead of the trails beginning is open.

title: Royal Palm
listingDescription: Royal Palm Information Station and Bookstore is a great place to stop to see wildlife, walk trails, attend a ranger program, or purchase souvenirs. The gift shop is open year-round from 9AM-4PM. Attend a ranger talk or follow a ranger on a guided walk beginning at the Royal Palm Visitor Center. Royal Palm serves as the terminus of two wheelchair accessible trails, the Anhinga Trail and Gumbo Limbo Trails, each offering visitors the opportunity to explore a different ecosystem

images.altText: Sun hits a white building, and birds perch on the green roof. Building faces a still lake
images.title: Royal Palm Visitor Area
images.caption: Royal Palm visitor area in the morning

bodyText: Royal Palm Information Station and Bookstore is a great place to stop to see wildlife, walk trails, attend a ranger program, or purchase souvenirs. The gift shop is open year-round from 9AM-4PM. Attend a ranger talk or follow a ranger on a guided walk beginning at the Royal Palm Visitor Center. Royal Palm serves as the terminus of two wheelchair accessible trails, the Anhinga Trail and Gumbo Limbo Trails, each offering visitors the opportunity to explore a different ecosystem along a paved trail or boardwalk. The Royal Palm area became a state park in 1916 before it became one of the original parts of Everglades National Park in 1947.
audioDescription: As you approach Royal Palm, you will find a large parking lot with two rows of parking. The building adjacent to the parking lot is equipped with restrooms, water fountains, vending machines, and an information station and bookstore. Just past the visitor center, an overhang shades an area of benches where daily talks and ranger-guided walks begin. Past the building, a paved path meanders along a freshwater slough, home to animals such as alligators, fish, turtles, and anhingas. Follow the paved path to access two wheelchair accessible paved and boardwalk trails, the Anhinga and Gumbo Limbo Trails.

title: Sandfly Hiking Trail
listingDescription: Sandfly Island Hiking Trail

images.altText: A wooden boardwalk through a dense forest of mangrove trees
images.title: Sandfly Island Hiking Trail
images.caption: Sandfly Island Hiking Trail

bodyText: Sandfly Island appears wild and natural, like hundreds of other islands of mud and mangroves in this estuary. But the trail reveals many layers of human history. Pioneer homesteading is the most obvious; notice the old concrete cistern. Shell mounds and the shape of the shoreline indicate that the entire island was engineered. The earliest inhabitants, Calusa Indians, built the island in a horseshoe configuration to facilitate fishing with the aid of the tides and a net. The hiking trail 0.9 miles, visitors should allow 40 minutes to complete. The surface is bare ground and the trail is not wheelchair accessible.
audioDescription: The trailhead for the Sandfly Island Hiking trail is located on Sandfly Island. There is a damaged wooden boat dock and a single portable toilet near the trailhead. The toilet is housed in a blue, plastic container with a white, plastic top. The hiking trail is 0.9-miles long and is not accessible to wheelchairs. The trailhead is shaded by a dense canopy overhead. The ground is bare dirt with leaves scattered over it. There is an interpretive panel at the trailhead titled "Sandfly Island Trail" with a depiction of local indigenous people and the following text, "This key appears wild and natural, like hundreds of other islands of mud and mangroves in the estuary. But the trail reveals many layers of human history. Pioneer homesteading is the most obvious: notice the old concrete cistern. Shell mounds and the shape of the shoreline indicate that the entire island was engineered. The earliest inhabitants built the island in a horseshoe configuration." Beside this text is its translation in Spanish.

title: Sandfly Loop Paddling Trail
listingDescription: This trip is 5 miles and can take between 2.5 - 4 hours. Trip durations may vary if you walk the trail on Sandfly Island or if strong winds or unfavorable tides are present. If you decide to stop at Sandfly Island, please use the beach area next to the dock, as the dock can be slippery and dangerous. Always tie up your boat.

images.altText: A wooden dock extends from a vegetated island into calm water. A brown portable toilet sits on dock.
images.title: Sandfly Island Dock
images.caption: Sandfly Island Dock

bodyText: This trip is 5 miles and can take between 2.5 - 4 hours. Trip durations may vary if you walk the trail on Sandfly Island or if strong winds or unfavorable tides are present. If you decide to stop at Sandfly Island, please use the beach area next to the dock, as the dock can be slippery and dangerous. Always tie up your boat.
audioDescription: The trailhead for the Sandfly Loop Paddling Trail is located at the Gulf Coast canoe/kayak launch. The Sandfly Loop Paddling Trail is 5-miles long. The parking lot for the Gulf Coast boat launch is an unmarked, grassy area. The grass is worn and shows tire tracks from vehicles. There is a sandwich board sign in front of the boat launch with three signs taped to it. The first sign reads, “Stop! No parking pass this point. Loading and unloading only.” A second sign reads, “All park visitors are required to pay an entrance fee. Passes are not available at the visitor center while it is temporarily closed. Please visit recreation.gov and search for ‘Everglades National Park’ to purchase a pass.” A third sign reads, “Please complete a wilderness permit by the visitor center before any overnight trip.” The boat launch is located approximately northwest of the visitor center. On the south side of the boat launch is a green chain-link fence. On the other side of the fence is a National Park Service building with no public access to it. On the north side of the boat launch is a water spigot labeled “Drinking Water.” There are various canoes and kayaks stored on the south side of the boat launch. At the launch are five posts, three wooden and two metal, to prevent people from parking past them. North of the boat launch is a dense line of mangrove trees. On the south side of the boat launch is a black hose visitors can use to wash their boats. The ramp at the boat launch is made up of concrete squares 1’ x 1’. The ramp can be completely submerged by water at high tide and almost entirely exposed at low tide. There are many jagged, dark rocks with small mangrove trees shooting up between them on the south side of the ramp as you approach the water. Chokoloskee Bay is just west of the ramp. The bay is shallow and a ½-mile wide. Across the bay is a long, continuous line of mangrove trees. There are various navigation aids and channel markers in the bay visible from the boat launch. Some of the channel markers are brightly colored and shaped like triangles, others are green and shaped like squares.

title: Shark River Chickee
listingDescription: A single chickee structure located on the south shore of a branch of the Little Shark River, 0.3 miles south of WW marker #6. This is a shady site, with northern exposure. The chickee is tucked up against a tall red mangrove forest. The rattling and plopping and thunkings of the forest residents will be heard all night long.

images.altText: A roofed wooden platform with single, blue portable toilet. Green mangroves foliage is behind it
images.title: Shark River Chickee
images.caption: Backcountry chickees are a great place for solitude

bodyText:
A single chickee structure located on the south shore of a branch of the Little Shark River, 0.3 miles south of WW marker #6. This is a shady site, with northern exposure. The chickee is tucked up against a tall red mangrove forest. The rattling and plopping and thunkings of the forest residents will be heard all night long.

Access - Accessible by boat, canoe, and kayak at all tides. Be aware of the strong tidal current and plan your route accordingly. Wilderness Waterway travelers will access the chickee from the Little Shark River. Others may take on the challenge of the aptly named Labyrinth route and approach from the southeast.

Safely exploring a wilderness by water requires careful preparation and planning. Please visit our Wilderness Trip Planner page to learn more.
audioDescription: A chickee campsite with a single roofed square platform, open on all sides with a small offshoot for a vault toilet. Located on the southwestern shore of a branch of the Little Shark River, 0.3 miles south of Wilderness Waterway marker #6. This is a shady site, with northern exposure. The chickee is tucked up against a tall red mangrove forest. Accessible by boat at all tides and has a strong tidal current. It is accessed from the Little Shark River or the Labyrinth route approach from the southeast.

title: Shark Valley Entrance Station
listingDescription: Entrance booth to the Shark Valley District. All park passes are sold here. Open year round, hours vary due to season.

images.altText: Shark Valley Entrance Station
images.title: Shark Valley Entrance Station
images.caption: A small concrete square building with a white roof and a flagpole. An alligator sits on the roadside

bodyText: Entrance booth to the Shark Valley District. All park passes are sold here. Open year round, hours vary due to season.
audioDescription: A short spur road heads south from Highway 41 towards the Shark Valley District of Everglades National Park. Just 300 feet from the Highway a large limestone monument stands with the National Park Service emblem and Everglades National Park sign, a popular spot to take a photo. The road continues south, with a canal on one side, and large trees on the other. National Park Rangers will greet you as you enter past a small fee booth. This Entrance booth has one window to process one transaction at a time. Signs detailing hours, fees, and other frequently asked questions are posted by the fee window. There are no exhibits or additional visitor services at the Entrance Station. The parking lot and the visitor center are about 300 feet farther south. People are welcome to access Shark Valley by vehicle, bicycle, or by foot. Pets are only permitted in limited areas near the parking lot. A small, white hut staffed with National Park Service rangers greets visitors. This Entrance Station has one window to process one transaction at a time. Signs detailing hours, fees, and other frequently asked questions are posted by the fee window. There are no exhibits or additional visitor services at the Entrance Station. The parking lot and the visitor center is about 100 feet farther south. People are welcome to access Shark Valley by vehicle, bicycle, or by foot. Pets are permitted in very few areas.

title: Shark Valley Observation Tower
listingDescription: The highest elevation a visitor can reach by foot in the entire park, at 45 feet plus in elevation. Panoramic views up to 20 miles of the Everglades. Open year round and 24-hours a day.

images.altText: Spiraling concrete observation tower is silhouetted against a bright blue sky
images.title: Shark Velley Tower
images.caption: The high elevation of the Shark Valley Tower provides wonderful views of the Everglades

bodyText: The highest elevation a visitor can reach by foot in the entire park, at 70 feet in elevation. Panoramic views up to 20 miles of the Everglades are a favorite for visitors. The elevated view provides wonderful perspective of the diverse landscapes. Open year round and 24-hours a day.
audioDescription: The highest elevation in Everglades National Park is the Observation Tower in the Shark Valley district. To reach the tower, you must hike, bike, or take a tram tour. After traveling to the the southernmost point of the tram road, there is a paved path that leads to the observation tower. Along the path, animals are frequently found in a tree-lined pond dotted with aquatic vegetation. A water refill station and ADA accessible restrooms are at the base of the tower, as well as a sign detailing the hydrologic history of the area. The path climbs in a spiral motion, slowly ascending to 45 feet (14m) above the trees to a panoramic observation point. A green and brown patchwork of aquatic landscapes and ecosystems surrounds the tower. Alligators, turtles, and various bird species inhabit the water and trees below. Occasionally, a female crocodile is found nearby. At the top of the tower, several additional wayside exhibits discuss Native Americans and natural features of the terrain surrounding you.

title: Shark Valley Tram Trail
listingDescription: A 15-mile, flat paved loop trail, open year around, and only access to the Shark Valley Observation Tower. Great panoramic views of the Everglades along with wildlife sightings. Open 24-hours a day, year around.

images.altText: A concrete paved road winds through a sawgrass prairie. A white cattle egret stands on road
images.title: Shark Valley Tram Trail
images.caption: The Shark Valley tram Trail winds through the Shark Valley Slough

bodyText: A 15-mile, flat paved loop trail, open year around, and only access to the Shark Valley Observation Tower. Great panoramic views of the Everglades along with wildlife sightings. Open 24-hours a day, year around. This trail is popular for walking and bicycling because of its abundance of wildlife, particularly during the dry winter months.
audioDescription: This 15 mile (24 km one-way) paved loop road can be traveled by bike, by foot, or on a tram tour. The tram road is past the entrance station, just south of the parking lot and visitor center. This flat road travels past canals, tree islands, sawgrass prairies, sloughs and more. It is famously filled with alligators, herons, egrets, turtles, snail kites, and the occasional snake. Halfway down the trail, you reach a small parking lot for the tram buses with several bike stands for visitors. The tram road continues to the Shark Valley Observation Tower where water and restrooms are available.

title: Sisal Pond
listingDescription: Sisal Pond is freshwater borrow pit 15 miles from the park entrance. It can be accessed through the Long Pine Key Nature Trail or along the Main Park Road. Freshwater fishing is available.
bodyText: Sisal Pond is freshwater borrow pit 15 miles from the park entrance. It can be accessed through the Long Pine Key Nature Trail or along the Main Park Road. Freshwater fishing is available.

title: Snake Bight Hiking Trail
listingDescription: Snake Bight is 1.8 miles one way, but don't let the name deter you! In this play on words, a "bight" is actually a bay (Snake Bight) within a larger bay (Florida Bay). Enter another world as you travel through a tropical hardwood hammock, with dozens of tropical tree species. There is excellent bird watching from the boardwalk at the end of trail if you plan your hike or bike ride to arrive near high tide

images.altText: An unpaved path with overhanging green vegetation
images.title: Snake Bight Hiking Trail
images.caption: Snake Bight Hiking Trail features hardwood hammock and coastal habitats

bodyText: Snake Bight is 1.8 miles one way, but don't let the name deter you! In this play on words, a "bight" is actually a bay (Snake Bight) within a larger bay (Florida Bay). Enter another world as you travel through a tropical hardwood hammock, with dozens of tropical tree species. There is excellent bird watching from the boardwalk at the end of trail if you plan your hike or bike ride to arrive near high tide.
audioDescription: This bare ground trail begins around 10 feet to the south off the main park road and connected to a paved parking shoulder for several cars to the immediate right. A trail sign is posted an additional 10 feet in on the right side of the trail indicating the trail name and distance, availability for hikers and bicyclists, a trail map and then additional information. Dense vegetation walls and roofs the start of this trail.

title: Sweetwater Chickee
listingDescription: Sweetwater is a double chickee campsite located in a less frequently traveled area. Bring a free-standing tent with extra rope to tie it down. No hammering stakes or nails into chickee.

images.altText: A open air platform elevated over the water with two roofs and a blue portable toilet in between
images.title: Sweetwater Chickee
images.caption: Sweetwater Chickee

bodyText:
Sweetwater is a double chickee campsite located in a less frequently traveled area. Bring a free-standing tent with extra rope to tie it down. No hammering stakes or nails into chickee.

Safely exploring a wilderness by water requires careful preparation and planning. Please visit our Wilderness Trip Planner page to learn more.
audioDescription: Two 10’ x 12’ wooden platforms elevated above dark water. A wooden bridge connects both platforms. A blue plastic outhouse is on the middle of the bridge. Attached to each platform are gray, metal ladders. The chickee sits against heavy, green vegetation.

title: The Watson Place
listingDescription: At the turn of the century Ed Watson lived here in a two-story house growing vegetables and refining sugarcane. Historic objects can still be located including: a cement cistern, a sugarcane syrup cauldron, and farm machinery. Several exotic plant species still grow at this site. Visitors can camp at this backcountry ground site

audioDescription: There is a wooden dock floating on the water. Beyond the dock is a brown sign which reads “Watsons Place.” On the sign is a symbol of a tent and below is a smaller symbol showing that campfires are not allowed. In the middle of the site is an open area with short grass patches surrounded by heavy vegetation. In this space are two picnic tables that can sit six people. There are brick structures, an old kettle and metal wagons found throughout the area.

title: Turner River Paddling Trail
listingDescription: Turner River Canoe Trail information

images.altText: The bow of a kayak in the water and dense mangrove trees in front and to the side.
images.title: Turner River Canoe Trail
images.caption: Turner River Canoe Trail

bodyText:
To complete the entire Turner River Canoe Trail is a full day paddle. Sections can be done as an out and back. It is accessible from the canoe launch on US Hwy 41 in Big Cypress National Preserve or by launching from Chokoloskee or the Gulf Coast Visitor Center canoe launch. The total trail is 8.5 miles between Turner River Launch and Chokoloskee. Between Chokoloskee and the Gulf Coast Visitor Center launch adds an additional 3 miles. Allow 5-8 hours. From the Gulf Coast Visitor Center, the Halfway Creek-Left Hand Turner-Turner River loop is 11 miles.

The Turner River may be impassable if water levels are too high or too low. Check water levels at the Big Cypress Welcome Center. Alligators are in the area. Keep a safe distance and give them the right of way.
audioDescription: One of the trailheads for the Turner River Canoe Trail is located at the Gulf Coast canoe/kayak launch. The Turner River Canoe Trail is 11.5-miles long from the Gulf Coast canoe/kayak launch to the Turner River launch in Big Cypress National Preserve. The parking lot for the Gulf Coast boat launch is an unmarked, grassy area. The grass is worn and shows tire tracks from vehicles. There is a sandwich board sign in front of the boat launch with three signs taped to it. The first sign reads, “Stop! No parking pass this point. Loading and unloading only.” A second sign reads, “All park visitors are required to pay an entrance fee. Passes are not available at the visitor center while it is temporarily closed. Please visit recreation.gov and search for ‘Everglades National Park’ to purchase a pass.” A third sign reads, “Please complete a wilderness permit by the visitor center before any overnight trip.” The boat launch is located approximately northwest of the visitor center. On the south side of the boat launch is a green chain-link fence. On the other side of the fence is a National Park Service building with no public access to it. On the north side of the boat launch is a water spigot labeled “Drinking Water.” There are various canoes and kayaks stored on the south side of the boat launch. At the launch are five posts, three wooden and two metal, to prevent people from parking past them. North of the boat launch is a dense line of mangrove trees. On the south side of the boat launch is a black hose visitors can use to wash their boats. The ramp at the boat launch is made up of concrete squares 1’ x 1’. The ramp can be completely submerged by water at high tide and almost entirely exposed at low tide. There are many jagged, dark rocks with small mangrove trees shooting up between them on the south side of the ramp as you approach the water. Chokoloskee Bay is just west of the ramp. The bay is shallow and a ½-mile wide. Across the bay is a long, continuous line of mangrove trees. There are various navigation aids and channel markers in the bay visible from the boat launch. Some of the channel markers are brightly colored and shaped like triangles, others are green and shaped like squares.

title: West Lake
listingDescription: A great place for wildlife viewing, picnics, paddle trips, hiking adventures and more, West Lake is a great destination. Boating visitors are reminded that watercraft with engines of 6 horsepower or less are permitted on West Lake, but not beyond.

images.altText: An aerial view of West Lake shows a dense mangrove shoreline and murky muddy brown waters
images.title: West Lake
images.caption: Aerial view of West Lake showing docks and mangrove shoreline

bodyText: A great place for wildlife viewing, picnics, paddle trips, hiking adventures and more, West Lake is a great destination. Boating visitors are reminded that watercraft with engines of 6 horsepower or less are permitted on West Lake, but not beyond.
audioDescription: West Lake is reached via a short access road 31 miles (50 kilometers) from the park entrance and 7 miles from Flamingo Visitor Center. There are parking spaces on both sides of the road with two handicap spaces on the far right by the trailhead. A 15 by 60 foot green pavilion with a flat, black roof contains bathrooms with running water, 5 picnic tables, and two bear resistant trash cans. The pavilion is next to a 10 foot wide boat ramp and overlooks a small bay at the western edge of West Lake. Three small concrete piers provide spots to tie up boats. Boat motors are allowed only in West Lake with a maximum size of 6 horsepower. A sign at the top of the boat ramp provides information about the West Lake Canoe Trail.

title: West Lake Boardwalk
listingDescription: This self-guided boardwalk trail wanders through a forest of white mangrove (Laguncularia racemosa), black mangrove (Avicennia nitida), red mangrove (Rhizophora mangle), and buttonwood (Conocarpus erectus) trees to the edge of West Lake. Directions to Trail: Seven miles (11km) north of the Flamingo Visitor Center on the main park road.

images.altText: A gray composite boardwalk extends to the horizon. A man is fishing off the edge into the water
images.title: New West Lake Boardwalk
images.caption: Take a stroll through the mangroves on the West Lake Boardwalk

bodyText:
This self-guided boardwalk trail wanders through a forest of white mangrove (Laguncularia racemosa), black mangrove (Avicennia nitida), red mangrove (Rhizophora mangle), and buttonwood (Conocarpus erectus) trees to the edge of West Lake.

Directions to Trail: Seven miles (11km) north of the Flamingo Visitor Center on the main park road.
audioDescription: The West Lake Boardwalk is a 0.5 mile round trip on a wheelchair accessible boardwalk. This self-guided boardwalk trail wanders through a forest of white mangrove, black mangrove, red mangrove trees to the edge of West Lake. The trail extends over the shallow waters of West Lake.

title: West Lake Canoe Trail
listingDescription: Paddle through a series of large open lakes connected by narrow creeks lined with mangroves. Look for alligators and crocodiles. West Lake is closed to vessels with motors greater than 6 h.p. Motors are prohibited from the east end of West Lake through Alligator Creek. Not recommended on windy days due to open, rough waters. A wilderness permit is required for overnight stays.

images.altText: Kayakers in a yellow kayak relax on the sparkling blue waters of West Lake
images.title: West Lake Canoe Trail
images.caption: Kayakers paddling in West Lake

bodyText: Paddle through a series of large open lakes connected by narrow creeks lined with mangroves. Look for alligators and crocodiles. West Lake is closed to vessels with motors greater than 6 h.p. Motors are prohibited from the east end of West Lake through Alligator Creek. Not recommended on windy days due to open, rough waters. A wilderness permit is required for overnight stays.
audioDescription: When standing at the beginning of the West Lake Canoe Trail you will be looking west from a small boat ramp next to a concrete structure that butts up to the water with a roof on it. The structure has restrooms, picnic tables with a wooden railing around it, and steps that lead down to concrete jetties that stick out into the water with cleats on them. The water, a small shallow bay about 1-3 feet deep, is clean but dark in color with wispy vegetation growing from the bottom and sometimes sticking above the water. The bay is surrounded by red mangroves with openings on the north and south side. The West Lake Canoe Trail is approximately 35.9 miles for the main park entrance.

title: Whitewater Bay
listingDescription: Whitewater Bay is a large, open body of water that can prove challenging for some boaters. Strong winds and long distances can make this an arduous paddle for canoes and kayaks. Navigation can by tricky thanks to the monotony of the mangrove shoreline. Visitors are encouraged to use NOAA Chart #11433 to assist them in exploring this area.

images.altText: Gray dolphins stick their snouts and fins out of the blue green water of Whitewater Bay
images.title: Dolphins in Whitewater Bay
images.caption: Dolphins can be found swimming in Whitewater Bay

bodyText: Whitewater Bay is a large, open body of water that can prove challenging for some boaters. Strong winds and long distances can make this an arduous paddle for canoes and kayaks. Navigation can by tricky thanks to the monotony of the mangrove shoreline. Visitors are encouraged to use NOAA Chart #11433 to assist them in exploring this area.
audioDescription: This bay is connected with the Gulf of Mexico to the northwestern section and to Tarpon Creek and then Coot Bay to the southeast. If entering via the Buttonwood Canal and on to Tarpon Creek, Whitewater Bay is approximately 5 miles distant from the Flamingo marina. The bay’s tannin rich waters are typically dark in coloration and prone to white-capping in high winds. Numerous mangrove covered islets and surrounds can be found here and with dolphin sightings and wading birds fairly common. Overall dimensions of the bay are around 10 miles long by 6 miles wide.

title: Willy Willy
listingDescription: his campsite is located on an old Calusa Indian mound, shaded by tropical hardwood trees. A canoe can follow the narrow, winding creek that connects the west end of Rocky Creek Bay to Lostman’s Five Bay to explore a different route back to the W.W. Change your chart to show W.W. reroute of markers #35 to #39 in Rodgers River Bay.
